questions.text: A 26-year-old man comes to the emergency department for evaluation of acute testicular pain. The pain has been progressively worsening over the past five days. He has no pain with urination, but there is significant tenderness with manipulation of the scrotum. He is sexually active with two partners and does not use barrier protection. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 94/min, and blood pressure is 125/80 mmHg. Physical examination reveals pain with palpation of the right testis posteriorly. Stroking of the right inner thigh results in elevation of the right testis. Which of the following additional clinical findings will most likely be observed in this patient?

choices.text: Relief of pain with manual elevation of the right testis
Transverse lie of the right testis
Edematous and tender prostate on digital rectal examination
Tender nodule with blue discoloration on the upper pole of the right testis

questions.solution:
Epididymitis refers to an infection of the epididymis. In males less than 35 years old, this infection is most commonly associated with sexually transmitted organisms including Chlamydia trachomatis and, less commonly, Neisseria gonorrhoeae. In males older than 35 years, and those without sexual partners, the most common organisms are gram-negative bacteria, predominantly Escherichia coli. In some patients, the infection can spread to the testicle, resulting in orchitis. Isolated cases of orchitis are rare and are more often seen with viral etiologies (e.g. mumps).

It is important to differentiate epididymitis from testicular torsion, which is another cause of testicular and scrotal pain. The Prehn sign is a helpful differentiating physical examination maneuver that is typically positive in patients with epididymitis. The exam is considered positive when elevation of the affected testis results in relief of pain, whereas in testicular torsion, any testicular manipulation exacerbates the pain. Additionally, patients with epididymitis have an intact cremaster reflex, whereas patients with testicular torsion have an absent reflex.  

Option Analysis

✅ Relief of pain with manual elevation of the right testis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ High-riding right testis:
Incorrect: A high-riding testis occurs when the testis moves to a more superior scrotal position. This phenomenon occurs due to shortening of the spermatic cord with testicular torsion. This diagnosis is unlikely in this patient who is presented with testicular pain in the posterior testis, as well as an intact cremaster reflex.
❌ Transverse lie of the right testis:
Incorrect: Transverse lie of the testis can be seen in patients with testicular torsion. This diagnosis is unlikely in this patient who is presenting with testicular pain in the posterior testis, as well as an intact cremaster reflex.
❌ Edematous and tender prostate on digital rectal examination:
Incorrect: This answer describes prostatitis, which more often presents with fevers, chills, dysuria, and pelvic or perineal pain. This patient has none of these symptoms.
❌ Tender nodule with blue discoloration on the upper pole of the right testis:
Incorrect: This answer describes torsion of the appendix testes. Torsion of the appendix testis rarely occurs in adults. The pain in this condition is localized to the anterosuperior aspect of the testis.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman comes to the clinic with a history of vaginal bleeding immediately after sexual intercourse for the last 3 weeks. The patient has taken oral contraceptive pills for the past three months. Her menstrual cycles are regular and occur every 28 days and last for five days. Past medical history is significant for a gonococcal infection four years ago. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 120/75 mmHg.  On speculum examination, the cervix appears friable with mucopurulent discharge from the cervical os. Cervical motion tenderness is present. Vaginal swabs are sent to the lab and are pending. This patient should be empirically treated for which of the following organisms?
questions.solution:
This patient has evidence of cervical motion tenderness, a friable cervix, mucopurulent discharge, and vaginal bleeding after sexual intercourse. This presentation is consistent with acute cervicitis and pelvic inflammatory disease (PID).

Neisseria gonorrhea and Chlamydia trachomatis are the leading causes of acute cervicitis and pelvic inflammatory disease in patients with female genitalia who are sexually active. In addition to the aforementioned symptoms, associated symptoms may include dysuria, increased urinary frequency, and nonspecific pelvic pain or cramping. Diagnostic evaluation of suspected cervicitis includes a pelvic exam (including a speculum evaluation of the cervix) and nucleic acid amplification tests for both Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhea.

The presence of symptoms suggestive of PID or acute cervicitis requires prompt, empiric antibiotic treatment. Because coinfection with Neisseria gonorrhea and Chlamydia trachomatis is highly common, first-line outpatient therapy includes both intramuscular ceftriaxone and oral doxycycline, in order to cover both pathogens.  

Option Analysis

✅ Neisseria gonorrhoeae and Chlamydia trachomatis  :
Correct: See Main Explanation  
❌ Neisseria gonorrhoeae:
Incorrect: Treatment for acute cervicitis and pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) should always cover both Neisseria gonorrhoeae and Chlamydia trachomatis, given the high rate of coinfection. Treatment for one organism (e.g. with ceftriaxone alone) would be inappropriate.  
❌ Chlamydia trachomatis:
Incorrect: Treatment for acute cervicitis and pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) should always cover both Neisseria gonorrhoeae and Chlamydia trachomatis, given the high rate of coinfection. Treatment for one organism (e.g. with doxycycline alone) would be inappropriate.  
❌ Candida albicans:
Incorrect: Symptoms of vaginal candidiasis include currying white vaginal precipitate, as opposed to mucopurulent cervical discharge. In addition, this patient’s cervical motion tenderness and cervical friability are characteristic of a diagnosis of acute cervicitis and pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), which are not caused by Candida albicans.  
❌ Trichomonas vaginalis:
Incorrect: While patients with trichomoniasis often present with vaginal discharge, the discharge is characteristically malodorous, and patients often have the additional findings of dysuria and an erythematous, “strawberry” cervix (i.e. punctate hemorrhages). In contrast, this patient’s cervical motion tenderness and cervical friability are characteristic of a diagnosis of acute cervicitis and pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), which are not caused by Trichomonas vaginalis.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl is brought to the pediatrician by her parents for a routine health maintenance visit. The patient reports feeling well, and she has been meeting all developmental milestones. She has no chronic medical conditions. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 71/min, and blood pressure is 112/71 mmHg. She is at the 75th percentile for height and 80th percentile for weight. A vaccine that is protective against genital warts and cervical cancer is recommended by the pediatrician and administered during the visit. Which of the following best describes the characteristics of this vaccine and the pathogen that it protects against?
questions.solution:
In the United States, there is a human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccine called Gardasil. It is a subunit vaccine, meaning it only includes the antigens that best stimulate the immune system. This vaccine targets 9 HPV strains; the 7 high risk strains, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52 and 58, as well as 2 low-risk strains, 6 and 11. Low-risk strains are responsible for causing common warts (verruca vulgaris) and anogenital warts (condyloma accuminata). The high-risk strains are most commonly the cause of cervical cancer. The vaccine is generally administered between 11-12 years of age. 

Option Analysis

❌  Vaccine Type Pathogen Characteristics Inactivated  DNA Virus :
Incorrect: Inactivated vaccines use a pathogen that has been killed by heat or chemicals. Examples include the hepatitis A, polio, rabies, and influenza vaccines. However, none of these vaccines are protective against cervical cancer or genital warts, both of which are caused by HPV.
❌  Vaccine Type Pathogen Characteristics Inactivated  RNA Virus:
Incorrect: Inactivated vaccines are protective against many RNA viruses. These include the hepatitis A, polio, rabies, and influenza vaccines. However, the vaccine protective against cervical cancer and genital warts is a subunit vaccine against HPV.
✅  Vaccine Type Pathogen Characteristics Subunit DNA Virus :
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌  Vaccine Type Pathogen Characteristics Subunit RNA Virus:
Incorrect: The HPV vaccine, which protects against genital warts and cervical cancer, is a subunit vaccine. However, HPV is a DNA virus.
❌  Vaccine Type Pathogen Characteristics  Live-attenuated DNA Virus :
Incorrect: Live-attenuated vaccines can protect against conditions caused by DNA viruses, such as varicella and smallpox. Cervical cancer and genital warts are both caused by the DNA virus HPV. However, the vaccine used to prevent HPV is a subunit vaccine.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man comes to the clinic with inguinal ulcers that he noticed two days ago. He is sexually active and began a relationship with a new partner one month ago. They use condoms inconsistently. He immigrated from Papua New Guinea two months ago. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 120/75 mmHg. The abdomen is soft and nontender. Shallow, nontender ulcers are noted along the shaft and base of the penis with associated erythema. Painful, bilateral inguinal lymphadenopathy is present. An additional flesh-colored papule is noted at the base of the penis. Which of the following is most likely the causative organism responsible for this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient has evidence of a non-tender papule, multiple painless ulcers and painful inguinal lymphadenopathy. These findings suggest lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV), which is caused by serotypes L1-L3 of Chlamydia trachomatis.

LGV begins as a primary infection in the genitals and spreads via a direct extension to draining lymph nodes in the pelvis (superficial and deep inguinal lymph nodes). The primary infection is usually indolent and is often missed as it is not associated with accompanying symptoms (though in some cases, proctitis may be the initial presenting symptom). This lymphatic infection ultimately results in a lymphoproliferative inflammatory reaction and painful lymphadenopathy. However, in individuals with female genitalia, lymphadenopathy is unlikely as the vagina and the cervix drain to the retroperitoneal lymph nodes (not the inguinal lymph nodes).

If these lesions are left untreated, the infection can progress to the formation of painful inguinal buboes with subsequent lymphatic fibrosis and stricture formation. Diagnosis is accomplished via nucleic acid amplification testing of sample fluid.

Genital ulcers in sexually active individuals raise concern for infection from several organisms, which requires prompt identification and treatment. Recalling the nature of the ulcer (painful vs. painless, multiple vs. single) and features of lymphadenopathy can assist in diagnosis, as outlined in the table below.
 


Option Analysis

✅ Chlamydia trachomatis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Treponema pallidum:
Incorrect: Syphilis is caused by the spirochete Treponema pallidum. Clinical manifestations include a single, nontender genital ulcer. Painful, purulent lymphadenopathy or buboes would be atypical.  
❌ Herpes simplex virus-2:
Incorrect: Herpes simplex infection typically causes multiple, painful genital ulcers. This patient’s ulcers are nontender.  
❌ Neisseria gonorrhoeae:
Incorrect: Neisseria gonorrhoeae causes urethritis in individuals with male genitalia, presenting with purulent urethral discharge and pruritus. This patient’s nontender ulcers and painful lymphadenopathy suggests an alternative diagnosis.  
❌ Haemophilus ducreyi:
Incorrect: Haemophilus ducreyi causes chancroid, which presents with multiple, tender purulent genital ulcers. This patient’s ulcers are nontender.

questions.text:
A 22-year-old man comes to an outpatient clinic for evaluation of pain and increased frequency of urination for the past four days. The patient endorses penile discharge and is concerned he “may have a urinary tract infection.” The patient is currently sexually active with three partners. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 120/75 mmHg. External genital examination reveals mucopurulent, cloudy discharge at the urethral meatus. Digital rectal exam (DRE) is within normal limits. Findings from a urinalysis are demonstrated below. Gram staining of the discharge is negative for the presence of bacteria. Urine culture is negative for growth at 24 hours. Which of the following findings is most likely to be found on further evaluation?
 
Laboratory value  
Result
Urinalysis  

Color
Cloudy
Specific gravity  
1.013  
Glucose
Negative
Blood
Negative  
Leukocyte esterase  
Large leukocyte esterase  
Nitrites
Negative  
Leukocytes  
50-100/hpf  
Erythrocytes  
1-2/hpf  
Dysmorphic RBCs  
Absent  
Casts  
None

choices.text: Nucleic acid amplification of a gram-negative bacterium
KOH wet mount with motile trichomonads

questions.solution:
This patient presents with characteristic features of chlamydial urethritis including dysuria, penile mucopurulent discharge, sterile pyuria, and a negative gram stain and culture. Confirmatory diagnosis is made via nucleic acid amplification testing.

Chlamydia trachomatis is a gram-negative, predominantly intracellular bacterium that is transmitted sexually. Infection with chlamydia trachomatis should be suspected in patients with multiple sexual partners who present with symptoms of either urethritis (in patients with male genitalia)or cervicitis (in patients with female genitalia). The serotypes that are responsible for urethritis, cervicitis, and pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) include serotypes D-K. Of note, Neisseria gonorrhoeae coinfects a significant proportion of patients with chlamydial infections.

Most biologically male patients with chlamydial infections are asymptomatic; however, common clinical manifestations of male chlamydial urethritis include dysuria, increased urinary frequency, penile discharge, and pruritus. Urethral discharge may be mucoid or watery. In contrast, infection in biological females presents with symptoms of cervicitis including vaginal discharge, pelvic pain, vaginal bleeding, or mucopurulent discharge on speculum examination.

Neisseria gonorrhoeae may also cause symptoms of urethritis and cervicitis and present in a similar manner to chlamydial urethritis/cervicitis. However, gonorrhoeal cervicitis/urethritis typically involves more copious urethral/vaginal discharge, and diagnosis is confirmed by the presence of gram-negative intracellular diplococci within polymorphonuclear leukocytes with gram stain and microscopy. By comparison, chlamydial infections cannot be detected by traditional stains and culture due to the absence of murein in its cell wall. Therefore, the diagnostic test of choice for chlamydial infection is a nucleic acid amplification test. Vaginal and cervical swabs are obtained in patients with female genitalia, and urine samples are analyzed in patients with male genitalia.  

Option Analysis

✅ Nucleic acid amplification of a gram-negative bacterium  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ KOH wet mount with motile trichomonads  :
Incorrect: Trichomonas is an uncommon cause of urethritis. Motile trichomonads on a wet mount analysis may indicate trichomonal urethritis. Microscopy of urethral samples is insensitive in patients with male genitalia, although they may be positive for cervicitis in patients with female genitalia.  
❌ Ring-enhancing prostatic lesions on CT:
Incorrect: A CT scan is not indicated in the evaluation of uncomplicated urethritis. CT scans may be used for the evaluation of prostatic abscesses, which may mimic the symptoms found in this patient; however, this patient has a negative DRE, making this diagnosis unlikely.  
❌ Positive hepatitis B surface antigen:
Incorrect: Hepatitis B antigen is diagnostic of hepatitis B infection. Most patients are asymptomatic or present with a febrile illness and icterus. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with chlamydial urethritis.  
❌ Positive VDRL serology:
Incorrect: VDRL is a preliminary investigation for the diagnosis of syphilis. Primary syphilis presents with an isolated, nontender chancre on the external genitalia. Dysuria and urethral discharge are uncommon in primary syphilis.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman comes to a primary care physician’s clinic with fever, generalized muscle aches, and painful perineal ulcers. The patient had similar symptoms four months ago and did not seek treatment. Two months ago, she was diagnosed with acute cervicitis and treated with a course of ceftriaxone and doxycycline. She is sexually active and began a non-monogamous relationship with a new partner six months ago. They use condoms inconsistently. The patient has never traveled outside the country. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 120/75 mmHg. The abdomen is soft and nontender. External genital examination reveals multiple tender ulcers on the labia majora. Cervical motion tenderness is absent on bimanual examination. Bilateral tender inguinal lymphadenopathy is noted. Which of the following findings is likely to be seen on further laboratory evaluation?

choices.text: Multinucleated giant cells and intranuclear inclusion bodies
RNA virus with intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies

questions.solution:
This patient presents with multiple, painful genital ulcers and a history of inconsistent condom use; this presentation has typical features of genital herpes infection. Microscopic evaluation via a Tzank smear will likely reveal multinucleated giant cells and intranuclear inclusion bodies.

Two serotypes of the herpes simplex virus are responsible for inducing herpes genitalis: HSV-1 and HSV-2 (with HSV-2 being implicated in genital infections in most cases). Transmission of genital herpes infection occurs through unprotected sexual intercourse (i.e., oral, vaginal, or anal sex). Clinical manifestations of primary genital HSV include multiple, grouped, painful genital ulcers with an erythematous base, tender inguinal lymphadenopathy, and systemic symptoms of fever, headache, malaise, and myalgias. Individuals with male genitalia may also present with symptoms of proctitis, particularly in individuals who engage in unprotected anal sex. Symptoms of acute proctitis include rectal pain, bleeding, and purulent rectal discharge with diffuse tenderness on digital rectal examination.

Diagnosis is primarily clinical; however, viral culture and PCR-based testing are often performed. Histologically, Tzanck smear will demonstrate multinucleated giant cells with intranuclear inclusion bodies known as Cowdry bodies.

Option Analysis

✅ Multinucleated giant cells and intranuclear inclusion bodies:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ RNA virus with intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies:
Incorrect: Molluscum contagiosum is an RNA poxvirus that causes multiple, nontender, small, flesh-colored papules with central umbilication and eosinophilic intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with genital herpes infection.
❌ Reactive VDRL test:
Incorrect: A diagnosis of syphilis is supported by a positive VDRL test. Clinical features of syphilis include a single, nontender, indurated genital ulcer and painless inguinal lymphadenopathy. This patient has evidence of multiple painful genital ulcers and tender lymphadenopathy, which is more consistent with genital herpes infection.  
❌ Gram-negative rods on microscopy:
Incorrect: Chancroid is caused by Haemophilus ducreyi. Although the classic presentation of chancroid includes purulent genital ulcers and painful inguinal lymphadenitis, this patient’s pattern of recurrence (i.e. similar symptoms four months ago) and the physical description of the lesions instead point toward a diagnosis of genital herpes infection.  
❌ Deeply staining gram-negative intracytoplasmic cysts:
Incorrect: Certain serovars of Chlamydia trachomatis (L1-L3) can cause lymphogranuloma venereum. Clinical manifestations include painless, small, shallow genital ulcers and painful coalesced inguinal lymph nodes. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with genital herpes infection.

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman comes to the clinic with a history of burning micturition, increased frequency of urination, and malodorous vaginal discharge. She is sexually active with three sexual partners. Her male partner does not use condoms when engaging in vaginal intercourse. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 120/75 mmHg. The patient’s abdomen is soft and nontender. Speculum examination reveals purulent, malodorous discharge and a friable, erythematous cervix with punctate hemorrhages. Cervical motion tenderness is absent on bimanual examination. The pH of the vaginal discharge is 5.5. An external genital examination is unremarkable.  Which of the following findings is likely to be seen on further laboratory evaluation?

choices.text: Motile trichomonads on wet mount microscopy
Detection of multinucleated cells on Tzanck smear
Gram-negative rods organized in parallel strands

questions.solution:
This patient presents with symptoms of dysuria and malodorous, purulent discharge, and the physical exam reveals an erythematous cervix and punctate hemorrhages (“strawberry cervix”). This presentation is consistent with trichomoniasis, which is caused by infection with the organism Trichomonas vaginalis.

Trichomoniasis is a sexually transmitted genitourinary infection that often presents with dysuria, purulent, malodorous vaginal discharge, and dyspareunia. The presence of motile trichomonads on wet mount microscopy confirms the diagnosis, and NAAT (nucleic acid amplification testing) is also specific and sensitive for the detection of this condition. Additional clues for the diagnosis include an elevated vaginal pH (greater than 4.5) and an increase in polymorphonuclear leukocytes on microscopy.

After diagnosis, treatment should be offered to both symptomatic and asymptomatic patients as well as  their sexual contacts. The treatment of choice includes a course of oral metronidazole.

Option Analysis

✅ Motile trichomonads on wet mount microscopy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Detection of multinucleated cells on Tzanck smear  :
Incorrect: Multinucleated cells on Tzanck smear indicate the presence of herpes simplex virus. Herpes simplex genital infection presents with multiple, painful genital ulcers. This patient’s presentation is instead more consistent with trichomoniasis.  
❌ Gram-negative rods organized in parallel strands:
Incorrect: Haemophilus ducreyi appears as gram-negative rods in parallel strands (or a “school of fish” appearance) on gram staining. The clinical infection manifests with multiple, painful, genital ulcers and tender lymphadenopathy. This patient’s presentation is instead more consistent with trichomoniasis.  
❌ Spirochetes on darkfield microscopy:
Incorrect: Primary syphilis manifests with a single, nontender genital papule or ulcer. Cervicitis and purulent, malodorous discharge would be atypical; this patient’s presentation is instead more consistent with trichomoniasis.  
❌ Positive whiff amine test  :
Incorrect: Bacterial vaginosis infection often yields a positive whiff test. While patients with bacterial vaginosis may have an elevated vaginal pH (normal 3.8-4.5) as in this case, the discharge associated with bacterial vaginosis is typically characterized as homogenous and gray-white with a fishy odor. This patient’s presentation is instead more consistent with trichomoniasis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man comes to the clinic for evaluation of multiple, painless, wart-like genital lesions that have been present for one week. The patient is sexually active and has had two sexual partners in the last month. He uses condoms inconsistently during sexual intercourse. The patient went on a week-long hike in New Hampshire two weeks ago. Temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 120/75 mmHg. Physical examination reveals a diffuse macular rash over the patient’s trunk and extremities with involvement of the palms and soles of the feet. The abdomen is soft and nontender. External genital examination reveals multiple flat topped and non-tender wart-like lesions over the penile shaft. Which of the following tests is most likely to reveal this patient’s underlying diagnosis?

choices.text: Indirect immunofluorescence antibody assay for immunoglobulin G (IgG) Rickettsii antigen

questions.solution:
This patient with a history of unsafe sexual practices (inconsistent condom use, multiple sexual partners) presents with painless genital warts, a fever, diffuse lymphadenopathy, and a diffuse macular rash involving the palms and soles of the feet. This presentation is characteristic for secondary syphilis and condylomata lata.

Serologic tests for the diagnosis of syphilis include both non-treponemal and treponemal tests.  Nontreponemal tests include detecting antibodies to reagin antigen, a cardiolipin-cholesterol-lecithin antigen (RPR testing), and VDRL (Venereal Disease Research Lab) testing. However, it should be noted that these tests are used for screening purposes given their high sensitivity and lower specificity. The level of antibodies present at the time of administration of these tests can predict the activity of a spirochete infection. However, given their low specificity, false-positive VDRL tests are commonly encountered due to infection with infectious mononucleosis or in patients with lupus, antiphospholipid antibody syndrome, rheumatic fever, leprosy, pregnancy, and those using medications such as phenothiazines (chlorpromazine and procainamide).

Specific treponemal tests include the FTA-ABS (fluorescent treponemal antibody absorption test),  microhemagglutination test for T. pallidum antibodies, and T. pallidum enzyme immunoassay (TP-EIA). In contrast to non-treponemal tests, these assays are highly specific, as they detect specific antibodies to treponemal antigens. Confirmatory tests include direct visualization of the spirochete under dark field microscopy, direct fluorescent antibody testing, and PCR testing for T. pallidum DNA.

Option Analysis

✅ Fluorescent treponemal antibody adsorption tests:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Wet mount microscopy:
Incorrect: Wet mount microscopy is useful for evaluating for the presence of bacterial vaginosis, trichomonas, or candidal infections. However, this patient’s presentation is more consistent with secondary syphilis.  
❌ Tzanck smear:
Incorrect: Herpes simplex virus causes a genital infection characterized by multiple tender ulcers over the external genitalia. A Tzanck smear may be used to aid in the diagnosis. However, this patient’s presentation is more consistent with secondary syphilis.  
❌ Indirect immunofluorescence antibody assay for immunoglobulin G (IgG) Rickettsii antigen:
Incorrect: Rocky mountain spotted fever is transmitted by a tick bite and can manifest with nonspecific symptoms like fever, generalized malaise, and a blanching, erythematous rash that begins on the ankles and wrists and spreads to the trunk. Wart-like genital lesions would be atypical. This patient’s presentation is instead more consistent with secondary syphilis.  
❌ Parvovirus B-19 DNA testing:
Incorrect: Erythema infectiosum predominantly affects children and is characterized by an erythematous rash that begins in the malar region and spreads to the trunk and extremities. Genital involvement is uncommon. This patient’s presentation is instead more consistent with secondary syphilis.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman comes to her primary care physician's clinic for evaluation of one week of burning urination, increased urinary frequency, and spotting after sexual intercourse. She was diagnosed with herpes simplex genital infection two months ago. She is sexually active with one male partner and uses condoms inconsistently. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 120/75 mmHg. On physical exam, the abdomen is soft and nontender. External genital examination reveals three healed, nontender genital ulcers. Speculum examination reveals mucopurulent discharge and a friable erythematous cervix. Cervical motion tenderness is absent. Which of the following findings is most likely on laboratory evaluation?

choices.text: Gram-negative rods in a “school of fish” chain

questions.solution:
This patient presents with vaginal discharge, spotting, dysuria, and a friable, erythematous cervix on clinical examination–suggestive of acute cervicitis. The most common causes of acute cervicitis include Neisseria gonorrhea and Chlamydia trachomatis.

In patients with female genitalia, infection with Neisseria gonorrhea presents with purulent or mucopurulent cervical discharge and/or vaginal bleeding. Physical examination findings include a friable, erythematous cervix with copious purulent discharge. Diagnostic studies include a gram stain and culture of vaginal fluid or an endocervical sample with microscopy and culture. A gram stain will demonstrate gram-negative diplococci within polymorphonuclear leukocytes.

NAAT (nucleic acid amplification test) is indicated in the diagnostic evaluation of acute cervicitis to evaluate for the presence of both Neisseria gonorrhea and Chlamydia trachomatis, which cannot be detected with traditional gram stain and culture. The presentation of cervicitis due to Neisseria gonorrhea is similar to that caused by Chlamydia trachomatis, although gonorrhea involvement is more likely to cause purulent or mucopurulent discharge. Because coinfection with the two pathogens is common, symptomatic patients are empirically treated for both with intramuscular ceftriaxone and a macrolide or tetracycline (doxycycline).

Meanwhile, in patients with male genitalia, infection with Neisseria gonorrhoeae results in urethritis and copious urethral discharge. Patients may have additional symptoms of dysuria, increased urinary frequency, and pruritus. Diagnostic workup similarly involves gram stain, culture and NAAT evaluation of a urethral sample.  

Option Analysis

✅ Diplococci within polymorphonuclear leukocytes:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Positive hepatitis B surface antigen:
Incorrect: Hepatitis B antigen is diagnostic of hepatitis B infection. Most patients are asymptomatic or present with a febrile illness and icterus. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with acute cervicitis.  
❌ Multinucleated cells on Tzanck smear  :
Incorrect: Herpes simplex virus can be diagnosed by performing a Tzanck smear, which will demonstrate the presence of multinucleated cells. Most patients present with painful genital ulcers, dysuria, and tender lymphadenopathy. This patient does not have evidence of an active HSV-2 infection.  
❌ Spirochetes on dark field microscopy:
Incorrect: Darkfield microscopy is used to diagnose syphilis. Primary syphilis typically presents with a single nontender genital chancre. This patient’s presentation with vaginal discharge, spotting, and dysuria is more consistent with acute cervicitis secondary to Neisseria gonorrhea or Chlamydia trachomatis.  
❌ Gram-negative rods in a “school of fish” chain:
Incorrect: Haemophilus ducreyi presents with painful genital ulcers and suppurative lymphadenopathy. Gram stain reveals gram-negative rods with a “school of fish” appearance. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with acute cervicitis secondary to Neisseria gonorrhea or Chlamydia trachomatis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man comes to a clinic for evaluation of ulcerative genital lesions for two weeks. The lesions have progressively increased in size with increasing purulent discharge. He is sexually active and began a monogamous relationship with a new male partner six months ago. He has had three sexual partners in his lifetime. Past medical history is significant for Crohn disease. He immigrated from India three months ago. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 120/75 mmHg. On physical exam, the abdomen is soft and nontender. Inguinal lymph nodes appear normal. Genital examination reveals multiple non-tender ulcers along the shaft and base of the penis with associated purulent discharge. Which of the following findings is likely to be seen on further laboratory evaluation?

choices.text: Gram-negative bacteria with intracytoplasmic cysts and deeply staining bodies
Multinucleated cells with intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies
Gram-negative rods organized in parallel strands

questions.solution:
This patient has symptoms of multiple purulent, non-tender genital ulcers without associated lymphadenopathy. In addition, this patient’s history of recent immigration from India raises suspicion of granuloma inguinale or Donovanosis–a sexually transmitted infection caused by the gram-negative bacteria Klebsiella donovanosis.

Clinically, this infection begins with the development of painless papules that progress to extensive, beefy red, nontender ulcers with associated purulent discharge. The majority of patients with this condition do not have regional lymphadenopathy. Anatomic areas commonly affected in individuals with female genitalia include the labia majora and minora and the fourchette. In individuals with male genitalia, the penile shaft is most commonly affected.

Diagnostic evaluation involves bipolar staining of ulcerative fluid which reveals gram-negative bacteria with intracytoplasmic cysts and deeply staining bodies resembling “safety pins.” Donovanosis is rarely encountered in the United States, but it is a cause of genital infections in tropical countries including India, Papua New Guinea, the Caribbean, South America, and Australia.

Genital ulcers in sexually active individuals raise concern for infection from several organisms, which requires prompt identification and treatment. Recalling the nature of the ulcer (painful vs. painless, multiple vs. single) and features of lymphadenopathy can assist in diagnosis, as outlined in the table below.
 
 

Option Analysis

✅ Gram-negative bacteria with intracytoplasmic cysts and deeply staining bodies:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Gram-negative diplococci within polymorphonuclear leukocytes:
Incorrect: Neisseria gonorrhoeae causes urethritis in individuals with male genitalia. Symptoms include purulent urethral discharge and dysuria. Genital ulcers are not found in this condition.  
❌ Multinucleated cells with intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies:
Incorrect: Herpes simplex genitalis infection does cause multiple genital ulcers; however, they tend to be painful and associated with tender lymphadenopathy as opposed to the nontender ulcers observed in this patient.  
❌ Spirochetes under dark field microscopy:
Incorrect: Primary syphilis typically presents with a single, nontender genital chancre or ulcer. This patient instead has multiple nontender purulent ulcers.  
❌ Gram-negative rods organized in parallel strands:
Incorrect: Microscopic analysis of Haemophilus ducreyi infection will reveal a  “school of fish” appearance. Clinically, patients present with multiple, tender purulent genital ulcers.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman comes to the emergency room with a fever, chills, and abdominal pain that began this morning. Two months ago, she was diagnosed with a herpes simplex genital infection and treated with valacyclovir. She is sexually active and has multiple sexual partners. She uses condoms inconsistently. Her last menstrual period was four weeks ago. She has not received the human papillomavirus vaccination series. Family history is noncontributory. Temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 120/75 mmHg. BMI is 32 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. Speculum examination reveals mucopurulent discharge with a friable, erythematous cervix. Cervical motion tenderness and right adnexal tenderness are present on bimanual examination. An external genital examination is non-contributory. Which of the following clinical sequelae is this patient at risk for if she does not receive appropriate treatment?

choices.text: Tenderness in the right upper quadrant

questions.solution:
This patient presents with symptoms of fever, abdominal pain, vaginal discharge, and cervical motion tenderness; the most likely diagnosis is pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). PID, if left untreated, can be followed by long-term complications including Fitz-Hugh Curtis syndrome (perihepatitis), which presents with right upper quadrant tenderness on physical examination.

Fitz-Hugh Curtis syndrome is an inflammatory condition of the hepatic capsule and adjacent peritoneal and pleural surfaces secondary to acute pelvic inflammatory disease. Clinical findings include those typical of pelvic inflammatory disease (cervical motion tenderness, mucopurulent discharge, fever) along with right upper quadrant pain and right-sided pleuritic pain. Laboratory evaluation is typically normal without evidence of transaminitis. On laparoscopy, gross liver morphology demonstrates purulent exudates and adnesions on the anterior surface of the liver, referred to as “violin string” adhesions.  

Option Analysis

✅ Tenderness in the right upper quadrant:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Postmenopausal bleeding:
Incorrect: The elevated estrogen levels associated with obesity is a significant risk factor for endometrial hyperplasia and endometrial cancer. While this patient’s BMI meets criteria for obesity, this current presentation with pelvic inflammatory disease does not increase this patient’s risk for developing endometrial cancer.  
❌ Axillary lymphadenopathy:
Incorrect: Risk factors of breast cancer include increasing age, female sex, obesity, positive family history, early menarche, and late menopause. However, this patient is presenting with pelvic inflammatory disease, which is not a risk factor for breast carcinoma.  
❌ Stress urinary incontinence:
Incorrect: Risk factors for pelvic organ prolapse and associated stress urinary incontinence include increasing parity, age, obesity, and a history of gynecological procedures. However, this patient is presenting with pelvic inflammatory disease, which is not a risk factor for pelvic organ prolapse or stress urinary incontinence.  
❌ Fixed uterus:
Incorrect: Clinical examination in endometriosis typically includes a tender, fixed uterus and tender nodules along the uterosacral ligaments. Risk factors associated with the development of endometriosis include nulliparity, late menopause, and early menarche. However, this patient is presenting with pelvic inflammatory disease, which is not a risk factor for endometriosis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man comes to a primary care clinic with fever, generalized muscle aches, and inguinal ulcers. Three months ago, he was diagnosed with acute urethritis and treated with a course of oral antibiotics. He is sexually active and began a monogamous relationship with a new partner three months ago. They use condoms inconsistently. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 120/75 mmHg. The abdomen is soft and nontender. External genital examination reveals multiple purulent, tender ulcers on the penile shaft. Tender inguinal lymphadenopathy is noted along with overlying ulcerative lesions. Histological analysis of one of these ulcers reveals an organism organized in parallel strands. Which of the following is the most likely organism responsible for this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with multiple painful genital ulcers and tender lymphadenopathy. Microscopic analysis indicates the presence of organisms organized in parallel strands (or a “school of fish” appearance). This description and clinical features are characteristic of Haemophilus ducreyi, the causative agent of the sexually transmitted infection chancroid.

Haemophilus ducreyi is a gram-negative rod transmitted through sexual contact, and clinical manifestations of the infection include multiple painful genital ulcers with a gray exudate and tender regional inguinal lymphadenopathy. One way to remember these clinical findings is that patients “do cry” when infected with H. ducreyi. Most lesions involve the penile shaft, prepuce, and glans penis in individuals with male genitalia. In individuals with female genitalia, the areas involved include the labia majora and minora, vaginal introitus, and the perianal regions. Diagnostic evaluation via gram stain will reveal gram-negative rods organized in parallel strands.

Genital ulcers in sexually active individuals raise concern for infection from several organisms, which requires prompt identification and treatment. Recalling the nature of the ulcer (painful vs. painless, multiple vs. single) and features of lymphadenopathy can assist in diagnosis, as outlined in the table below.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Haemophilus ducreyi:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Herpes simplex virus-2:
Incorrect: The clinical presentation of genital herpes includes multiple, shallow, tender vesicular genital ulcers. Histology of vesicular fluid typically shows multinucleated cells with intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with chancroid, which is caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.  
❌ Klebsiella granulomatis:
Incorrect: Donovanosis is caused by Klebsiella granulomatis, a gram-negative rod-shaped bacterium. Clinically, infection with this organism results in the presence of painless, ulcerative genital lesions without associated lymphadenopathy. This patient has painful genital lesions with lymphadenopathy, which is more consistent with chancroid, caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.  
❌ Treponema pallidum:
Incorrect: The classic clinical presentation of primary syphilis is a single, painless, indurated genital ulcer. This patient has multiple painful genital ulcers with lymphadenopathy, which is more consistent with chancroid, caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.  
❌ Chlamydia trachomatis:
Incorrect: Serotypes L1-L3 of Chlamydia trachomatis are responsible for developing lymphogranuloma venereum. This clinical entity presents with multiple, painless genital ulcers with painful lymphadenopathy. Histologically, this disease is characterized by the presence of epithelial cells with intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies. This patient has multiple painful genital ulcers with lymphadenopathy, which is more consistent with chancroid, caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of testicular pain and scrotal swelling. He had an episode of bilateral facial swelling along the jawline several days ago with associated fevers, headaches, and myalgias. The pain is worsened with movement. He has no dysuria. He is not sexually active. Records demonstrate his parents refused vaccinations throughout childhood. Temperature is 38.2°C (100.7°F), pulse is 98/min, and blood pressure is 122/84 mmHg. Physical examination reveals bilaterally enlarged and tender testicles. Stroking of the inner thigh bilaterally results in elevation of the testes. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s clinical condition?

choices.text: Retrograde urethral ascent of E. Coli
Infection with a double stranded DNA virus

questions.solution:
This adolescent male presents with features of orchitis (acute testicular inflammation). Given his prior symptoms of parotitis, viral prodrome (e.g., malaise, fever), and lack of vaccination, he likely suffered from mumps. The pathogen implicated in this condition is an RNA virus in the family of Paramyxoviridae. Mumps is the most common cause of viral orchitis (occurs in 20-30% of men with mumps infection), and it usually spreads to the testicles via the bloodstream.

Orchitis can also occur in the setting of a prior epididymal infection via a retrograde urethral infection. In this setting, pyogenic bacterial orchitis occurs as a consequence of contiguous spread from an inflammatory process in the epididymis, resulting in epididymo-orchitis. The majority of these cases are caused by E. coli, and patients with high-spiking fevers and associated SIRS criteria. In either case, orchitis is characterized clinically by testicular swelling and tenderness, with normal cremasteric reflexes.    

Option Analysis

✅ Infection with an RNA paramyxovirus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Dissemination of gram-negative Neisseria spp.:
Incorrect: Epididymis due to blood-borne dissemination of N. gonorrhoeae is possible, but patients typically have high-spiking fevers with associated SIRS criteria. This patient’s stable vital signs and symptoms suggest a different etiology.
❌ Retrograde urethral ascent of E. Coli:
Incorrect: Retrograde ascent of urethral pathogens via the ejaculatory duct into the vas deferens is the typical route of epididymal infections. Pathogens, like E. Coli, can spread to the testicles and result in orchitis. This patient’s symptoms (e.g., lack of vaccination, parotitis, orchitis) suggests a different etiology. Additionally, this patient is not sexually active, which is the major cause of epididymitis/orchitis in adolescents and young adults.
❌ Infection with a double stranded DNA virus :
Incorrect: Herpes simplex virus type 2 (HSV-2) can result in painful genital ulcers, dysuria, fever, and tender local inguinal lymphadenopathy. Viral spread to the lumbosacral ganglion can result in acute urinary retention. In contrast, this patient’s other symptoms (e.g., lack of vaccination, parotitis, orchitis) suggest a different etiology.
❌ Autoimmune inflammation :
Incorrect: Autoimmune orchitis is characterized by testicular inflammation and the presence of specific antisperm antibodies. Although it could explain this patient’s symptoms, the constellation of other signs and symptoms (e.g., lack of vaccination, parotitis, orchitis) suggests a different etiology.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman comes to the emergency room with a fever, chills, abdominal pain, and vaginal spotting that began this morning. Two months ago, she was diagnosed with primary syphilis and treated with intramuscular penicillin. She is sexually active with multiple sexual partners. She uses condoms inconsistently. Her last menstrual period was three weeks ago. She has not received the human papillomavirus vaccination series. Temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 120/75 mmHg. Speculum examination reveals mucopurulent discharge with a friable erythematous cervix. Cervical motion tenderness and right adnexal tenderness are present on bimanual examination. An external genital examination is non-contributory. Urine pregnancy testing is negative, and a trans-vaginal ultrasound is pending. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient who has multiple risk factors for a sexually transmitted infection (multiple sexual partners, inconsistent condom use) presents with symptoms of fever, abdominal pain, purulent vaginal discharge, right adnexal tenderness, and cervical motion tenderness. This presentation is most suggestive of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) complicated by a tubo-ovarian abscess.

Pelvic inflammatory disease involves the upper genital tract and often follows acute cervicitis. The condition is most commonly caused by the organisms Neisseria gonorrhea or Chlamydia trachomatis. Infection with these organisms results in disruption of the mucosal barrier, promoting transmission and colonization of the upper genital tract. Clinically, PID manifests with fever, abdominal pain, and purulent endocervical and/or vaginal discharge. On physical examination, cervical motion tenderness is often noted.

If untreated, or if there is a delay of treatment, pelvic inflammatory disease can result in long-term complications including tubo-ovarian abscesses, perihepatitis, salpingitis and infertility. A tubo-ovarian abscess refers to an abscess within the fallopian tube; the condition may present with adnexal tenderness on bimanual examination. Infertility may ultimately result as a sequelae of untreated PID as progressive scarring and adhesion formation within the fallopian tubes results in occlusion, fibrosis, and the loss of ciliary action.  

Option Analysis

✅ Tubo-ovarian abscess:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Ovarian torsion:
Incorrect: Ovarian torsion presents with acute, lancinating pelvic pain with associated nausea and vomiting. Fever and mucopurulent discharge are atypical of this condition.  
❌ Condyloma lata:
Incorrect: Condylomata lata are raised gray to white lesions found in the mouth or perineum that present with secondary syphilis. This patient was appropriately treated for a syphilitic infection.  
❌ Ruptured ectopic pregnancy:
Incorrect: A ruptured ectopic pregnancy can present with acute abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding; however, this patient’s urine pregnancy test is negative.  
❌ Condyloma acuminata:
Incorrect: Anogenital warts (flat, flesh-colored papules) caused by the HPV virus are termed condylomata acuminata. However, fever and vaginal discharge are atypical of this condition.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman comes to the clinic to evaluate perianal pruritus and genital lesions. Two months ago, she was diagnosed with acute cervicitis due to Neisseria gonorrhoeae and treated with outpatient antibiotics. She is sexually active and began a monogamous relationship with a new male partner three months ago. They use condoms inconsistently. The patient has had five sexual partners in her lifetime.  Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 120/75 mmHg. The abdomen is soft and nontender. External genital examination reveals several smooth, verrucous, skin-colored lesions over the labia majora and minora. Cervical motion tenderness is absent on bimanual examination. Which of the following describes the microorganism most likely responsible for this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with several verrucous genital lesions, consistent with condylomata acuminata due to an underlying human papillomavirus (HPV) infection (a non-enveloped DNA virus). Condyloma acuminata is most commonly caused by HPV strains 6 and 11, transmitted via oral, vaginal, and anal intercourse.

Clinical manifestations of condylomata acuminata include the presence of cauliflower-shaped, fungating, or flat-topped lesions on the groin, perineum, or perineal skin that are occasionally pruritic. In individuals with male genitalia, condylomata acuminata also develop along the penile shaft, and in those with female genitalia, lesions also develop on the vulva. In most cases, diagnosis of condylomata acuminata is clinical; however, in cases of diagnostic uncertainty, a biopsy and histological examination should be performed. Histologic examination often reveals koilocytosis, which refers to the presence of multiple vacuolated epithelial cells with enlarged, irregular nuclei.

Option Analysis

❌ Gram-negative diplococci:
Incorrect: Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a common cause of acute cervicitis and pelvic inflammatory disease, which typically presents with purulent cervical discharge, cervical motion tenderness, and intermenstrual spotting or bleeding. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with condylomata acuminata due to an underlying human papillomavirus (HPV) infection.  
✅ Non-enveloped DNA virus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Anaerobic gram-variable rods:
Incorrect: Gardnerella vaginalis can cause bacterial vaginosis, which clinically presents with clear or watery vaginal discharge. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with condylomata acuminata due to an underlying human papillomavirus (HPV) infection.  
❌ Motile, flagellated trichomonads:
Incorrect: Trichomonas vaginalis infection can cause mucopurulent vaginal discharge and an erythematous cervix. Infection with this organism does not result in the development of verrucous lesions. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with condylomata acuminata due to an underlying human papillomavirus (HPV) infection.  
❌ Encapsulated single-stranded RNA virus:
Incorrect: HIV is a single-stranded encapsulated RNA virus. Initial symptoms of infection with HIV include non-specific viral symptoms, including fevers and lymphadenopathy. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with condylomata acuminata due to an underlying human papillomavirus (HPV) infection (which is a non-enveloped DNA virus).

questions.text: A 2-day-old boy is brought to the emergency department due to fever and poor feeding. The child was born to a gravida 1 para 1 woman. He was born at home via normal vaginal delivery. The mother did not participate in routine prenatal visits and opted to give birth at home with assistance from a midwife. Temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F), heart rate is 200/min, blood pressure is 60/40 mmHg, and respiratory rate is 44/min. On physical examination, the child appears irritable and lethargic. The lungs, heart, and abdomen are clear on examination.  Blood workup reveals leukocytosis and elevated C-reactive protein. Bacterial cultures of the blood are positive for a Gram-positive ꞵ-hemolytic cocci. Which of the following interventions could have prevented this complication in this patient?

choices.text: No intervention could have prevented this complication
Avoidance of cold deli meats during pregnancy
Immediate vaccination of the newborn after delivery

questions.solution:
This infant has neonatal sepsis secondary to infection by Streptococcus agalactiae, which is also known as group B strep (GBS). The pathogen is a Gram-positive cocci that causes ꞵ-hemolysis on blood agar.  

GBS colonizes the vagina and birth canal and can lead to several complications during pregnancy and in the postpartum period for both the mother and fetus. During pregnancy, the pathogen can infect the placenta and amniotic fluid (chorioamnionitis), which can lead to miscarriage or stillbirth. During vaginal delivery, the neonate can be exposed to GBS in the birth canal, which can subsequently cause neonatal pneumonia, meningitis, and sepsis.  

To avoid these complications, pregnant women are screened for GBS with a vaginal and rectal swab between weeks 35-37 of gestation. If the screening test is positive, then intrapartum penicillin or ampicillin should be given as prophylaxis.

Option Analysis

✅ Intrapartum administration of ampicillin  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ No intervention could have prevented this complication:
Incorrect: This neonate most likely has sepsis secondary to infection by Streptococcus agalactiae, which is also known as group B strep (GBS). Prenatal screening and intrapartum administration of ampicillin decreases the risk of occurrence of GBS infection in neonates.
❌ Avoidance of cold deli meats during pregnancy:
Incorrect:Listeria monocytogenes can be transmitted by cold deli meat and can lead to neonatal sepsis during pregnancy or after birth; however, it is a Gram-positive bacilli, not cocci.
❌ Avoidance of breastfeeding:
Incorrect: Breastfeeding increases neonatal immunity and helps fight against infections. Avoidance of breastfeeding would not have helped prevent Streptococcus agalactiae sepsis.
❌ Immediate vaccination of the newborn after delivery:
Incorrect: There is no vaccine available for Streptococcus agalactiae, which is also known as group B strep (GBS).

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presents to the obstetrician for evaluation of foul-smelling vaginal discharge. Over the past two weeks, the patient has noticed a fishy vaginal odor. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 110/79 mmHg, and pulse is 72/min. Upon pelvic examination, gray-white discharge is apparent. She has never had a sexually transmitted infection but has recently been sexually active with a new partner. An amine whiff test is performed, which enhances the odor. The patient is started on a medication for the treatment of her symptoms. Three days later, while at a restaurant, she develops flushing, hypotension, nausea, and vomiting after consuming a glass of wine. Which of the following best characterizes the mechanism causing this reaction?
questions.solution:
This patient has a fishy-smelling vaginal odor and gray discharge. These findings are suggestive of bacterial vaginosis caused by Gardnerella vaginalis. She was most likely prescribed metronidazole, which causes a disulfiram-like reaction after consuming alcohol since the drug leads to acetaldehyde accumulation within the body.

Metronidazole is an antibiotic and antiprotozoal medication. It functions by generating toxic metabolites that damage pathogenic DNA. However, some of these metabolites inhibit the hepatic enzyme aldehyde dehydrogenase. Aldehyde dehydrogenase plays a vital role in ethanol metabolism by breaking down acetaldehyde into acetate. As a result, when patients consume alcohol while taking metronidazole, acetaldehyde builds up and produces symptoms of a disulfiram-like reaction (e.g., abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, flushing, headache).
   

Option Analysis

❌ Inhibition of alcohol dehydrogenase:
Incorrect: This patient most likely has bacterial vaginosis caused by Gardnerella vaginalis, often treated using metronidazole. Although metronidazole can cause a disulfiram-like reaction if the patient consumes alcohol while taking the drug, it does not inhibit the enzyme alcohol dehydrogenase.  
❌ Rapid accumulation of ethanol:
Incorrect: This patient was most likely started on metronidazole to treat bacterial vaginosis caused by Gardnerella vaginalis. Metronidazole does not directly cause excessive ethanol accumulation.  
❌ Accumulation of acetate:
Incorrect: Acetate is formed via the catalysis of acetaldehyde by the enzyme acetaldehyde dehydrogenase. Metronidazole inhibits this enzyme and causes the accumulation of acetaldehyde, not acetate.  
✅ Accumulation of acetaldehyde:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Deficiency of adequate reducing agents:
Incorrect: This patient was most likely started on metronidazole to treat bacterial vaginosis caused by Gardenrelalla vaginalis. Metronidazole does not deplete reducing agents required for the metabolism of alcohol.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old man comes to the office for the evaluation of a skin rash. It began a week ago on his trunk and has spread to his entire body now. He also reports low-grade fever, malaise, sore throat, and headache. The rest of the review of systems is unremarkable. He has had three female sexual partners over the past year. Past medical history is significant for type II diabetes mellitus managed with lifestyle modifications. Temperature is 37.2°C (99 F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 17/min and blood pressure is 130/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a full-body maculopapular rash as shown below. Several gray, mucosal patches are seen in the mouth. Cervical, axillary and epitrochlear lymphadenopathy is present. HIV testing is negative. The patient is administered an intramuscular dose of penicillin G and sent home. He later presents to the emergency department three hours later with a worsening rash, muscle pain, rigors, and chills. His temperature is now 38.3°C (100.9 F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min and blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s current symptoms?


Reproduced from Flickr
questions.solution:
This patient’s initial presentation with a diffuse maculopapular rash, oral lesions, and lymphadenopathy  (especially epitrochlear), in combination with a history of multiple sexual partners, is consistent with secondary syphilis. A single dose of intramuscular penicillin G-benzathine is the treatment of choice. The development of rigors, myalgias, further rise in the body temperature, increased respiratory rate, and hypotension within four hours of penicillin administration is most likely secondary to Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction (JHR).  

JHR is a short-lived immunologic response to antimicrobial treatment characterized by fever, onset of constitutional symptoms, and worsening of rash (if initially present). It typically begins two to eight hours after the initial dose of antibiotic is given and resolves spontaneously within 24 hours.    

The exact cause is unknown, but it is thought to result from accelerated phagocytosis by polymorphonuclear leukocytes followed by the release of bacterial toxins and/or lipoproteins and cytokines from killed organisms. Although the symptoms often resolve without intervention within 12 to 24 hours, non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) or other antipyretics can be used to decrease the severity. It can occur following the treatment of syphilis, Lyme disease, brucellosis, and enteric fever.  

Option Analysis

❌ Immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome:
Incorrect: Immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome is seen in some cases of AIDS or immunosuppression when the immune system starts to recover after the initiation of effective treatment of HIV or the removal of other causes of immunosuppression. A sudden increase in the inflammatory response produces nonspecific symptoms such as fever and in some cases a worsening of damage to the infected tissue. This patient was diagnosed with secondary syphilis and was subsequently started on an antibiotic therapy that triggered his current state. 
✅ Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Acute urticaria:
Incorrect: Acute urticaria refers to the development of dermal edema after the initiation of a new drug or exposure to an allergen. Presence of constitutional symptoms (rigors, myalgias, further rise in the body temperature, increased respiratory rate, and hypotension) is atypical.
❌ Procaine reaction:
Incorrect: Procaine reaction is a pseudo-anaphylactic reaction caused by unintentional intracapillary penetration of procaine penicillin during administration by intramuscular injection. Microembolization of the drug crystals can cause confusion and psychotic symptoms, which are not present in the Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction (JHR). The acute onset of the reaction and its brief duration (30 min) also differentiate it from JHR.
❌ Drug-induced hypersensitivity syndrome:
Incorrect: Drug-induced hypersensitivity syndrome is an idiosyncratic reaction consisting of fever, rash, eosinophilia, and internal organ involvement and tends to occur between 2-6 weeks after starting a new medication (as opposed to this patient’s presentation within 4 hours of penicillin administration). The most commonly implicated drugs include anticonvulsants, sulfonamides, and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs.

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman comes to the office because of vulvar pain and dysuria. She does not have increased urinary frequency or flank pain. She has never experienced similar symptoms before and her past medical history is unremarkable. The patient is sexually active and has had 4 sexual partners in the past year and uses condoms inconsistently. Current medications include a combined oral contraceptive and a hair vitamin. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows grouped shallow ulcers with erythema on the right labia majora. Right inguinal lymph nodes are tender to palpation. After further evaluation, the patient is started on an oral medication that requires a specific thymidine kinase for activation. Which of the following is an important adverse effect of the medication used in this patient when it is administered intravenously?
questions.solution:
This patient’s physical examination findings of grouped shallow genital ulcers with tender lymphadenopathy are consistent with herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection. Primary HSV infection is usually treated with acyclovir, which requires thymidine kinase for activation.  

Acyclovir is a guanosine analog that is effective against HSV-1, HSV-2, and varicella-zoster virus (VZV) infections. When used orally, it is only partially absorbed; therefore, it is used for mild mucocutaneous lesions and genital lesions or for herpes prophylaxis in immunocompromised individuals, such as individuals with AIDS. The oral drug is well tolerated but may cause gastrointestinal (GI) distress and headache. On the other hand, intravenous acyclovir is the treatment of more severe herpes infections, such as HSV encephalitis or neonatal HSV infection. Toxic effects of parenteral administration include delirium, tremor, seizures, hypotension, and nephrotoxicity (obstructive crystalline nephropathy and acute kidney injury). Acyclovir has no effect on latent forms of HSV and VZV. Resistance can involve changes in viral DNA polymerase or a mutation in viral thymidylate kinase.

Option Analysis

❌ Bone marrow suppression:
Incorrect: Bone marrow suppression is an important side effect of ganciclovir, which is effective against cytomegalovirus. This patient most likely has an HSV infection.
❌ Pancreatitis:
Incorrect: Pancreatitis is an important side effect of didanosine, a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor. Didanosine is not effective against HSV.
✅ Obstructive crystalline nephropathy:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Acute interstitial nephritis:
Incorrect: Acute interstitial nephritis is usually associated with exposure to beta-lactams and proton pump inhibitors. This patient’s HSV infection is most likely being treated with acyclovir.
❌ Disulfiram-like reaction:
Incorrect: Disulfiram-like reactions can occur commonly with metronidazole or griseofulvin, neither of which is effective against HSV.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the physician because of a six-month history of fatigue. He has also had a 7.7-kg (17-lb) weight loss during this period despite having a normal appetite. The patient is sexually active with three female partners and uses condoms inconsistently. The remainder of the review of systems is unremarkable. Past medical history is noncontributory. Vitals are within normal limits. An HIV screening test and confirmatory test are both positive. CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 550/mm<sup>3</sup> and viral load is 110 copies/mL. Treatment with lamivudine, didanosine, and indinavir is initiated. Which of the following adverse effects is this patient at greatest risk of developing due to this medication regimen?
questions.solution:
The patient in this vignette has a positive HIV test and is started on highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART). Didanosine is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI) and predisposes patients to acute pancreatitis. Of note, individuals taking didanosine may not develop pancreatitis until after many months of use, presumably due to the chronic accumulation of toxic metabolic products. Pancreatitis occurs more frequently in patients with alcohol use disorder or hypertriglyceridemia.  

Option Analysis

❌ Hyperpigmentation of palms and soles:
Incorrect: Hyperpigmentation is an adverse effect of emtricitabine, a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI), but not lamivudine, didanosine, or indinavir.  
✅ Acute pancreatitis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Vivid dreams:
Incorrect: Vivid dreams are an adverse effect of efavirenz, a non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NNRTI). NNRTIs can cause additional central nervous system symptoms (e.g., confusion, insomnia) and Stevens-Johnson syndrome. This patient, however, is not taking an NNRTI.  
❌ Megaloblastic anemia:
Incorrect: Megaloblastic anemia is an adverse effect of zidovudine, a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI), but not lamivudine, didanosine, or indinavir.  
❌ Obstructive crystalline nephropathy:
Incorrect: Obstructive crystalline nephropathy is an important adverse effect of acyclovir therapy, which can be avoided by adequate hydration.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents to the office for HIV testing. He recently learned that a previous sexual partner has tested positive for HIV infection. The patient is feeling well and has no acute symptoms. Past medical history is significant for seasonal allergies and asthma. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination is unremarkable. An HIV screening test and confirmatory test are both positive, and the physician informs the patient that he should be started on a multidrug antiretroviral therapy that includes lamivudine. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of lamivudine?

choices.text: Prevents complementary DNA synthesis from RNA template
Inhibits cleavage of viral polyprotein precursors
Inhibits viral genome integration into host cell
Prevents entry of viral core into host cytoplasm
Inhibits attachment of the virus to target cell surface

questions.solution:
Lamivudine is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI) used to treat HIV infection. This class of medication is an essential component of highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART).

NRTIs are prodrugs converted by host cell kinases to triphosphates. They inhibit nucleotide-binding from reversing transcriptase and terminating DNA chain elongation, given the NRTI molecules lack a 3′-OH group. NRTIs have no effect on completed proviral DNA already incorporated into CD4+ cells, and as a result, cells that are already infected remain infected. Therefore, NRTIs can only slow down the progression of the disease but not cure it. Examples of NRTIs include zidovudine, stavudine, lamivudine, didanosine, abacavir, and tenofovir.

Apart from being used in HAART, NRTIs can also be used in children born to mothers infected by HIV to reduce the risk of vertical transmission. Moreover, lamivudine can be used in the treatment of hepatitis B infection.

Side effects of NRTIs include gastrointestinal disturbances (e.g., nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain), bone marrow suppression, central nervous system toxicity (e.g., insomnia, headache, and peripheral neuropathy), and metabolic effects (e.g. lactic acidosis). In addition, abacavir can sometimes lead to fatal hypersensitivity reactions, whereas didanosine can cause pancreatitis.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Prevents complementary DNA synthesis from RNA template:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Inhibits cleavage of viral polyprotein precursors:
Incorrect: Protease is an HIV enzyme that cleaves the polypeptide products of HIV mRNA into their functional parts. This enzyme is inhibited by protease inhibitors (e.g., ritonavir, indinavir).  
❌ Inhibits viral genome integration into host cell:
Incorrect: Integrase is an enzyme produced by HIV that incorporates the viral genome into host chromosomes. Integrase inhibitors (e.g. raltegravir) reversibly inhibit HIV integrase.  
❌ Prevents entry of viral core into host cytoplasm:
Incorrect: Enfuvirtide is an antiviral fusion inhibitor that blocks viral attachment, penetration, and uncoating. It binds to the gp41 subunit of the HIV envelope glycoprotein, thereby preventing conformational changes and subsequent fusing of the virus with T-cells.  
❌ Inhibits attachment of the virus to target cell surface:
Incorrect: gp120 facilitates HIV attachment to the host cell by binding CD4 receptor and chemokine coreceptor CCR-5.  Maraviroc binds CCR-5 on the surface of T-cells/monocytes, thereby inhibiting interaction with gp120.

questions.text: A 26-year-old primigravida at 39 weeks gestation comes to the emergency room in active labor. She has had routine prenatal care. Medical history is significant for gestational diabetes mellitus. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 105/75 mmHg. She delivers a 4kg male baby. A 2nd-degree perineal tear is noted. Which of the following structures is most likely involved in this injury?
questions.solution:
This patient has a second-degree perineal tear following a difficult childbirth. A second-degree perineal tear involves injury to the perineal body.    

Perineal tears are a common obstetric injury following difficult vaginal childbirth. They are distinct from an episiotomy, an intentional enlargement of the vaginal introitus to facilitate delivery.  

An episiotomy is a surgical incision that involves the perineum and the posterior vaginal wall during the second stage of labor. Episiotomies are done to minimize perineal injuries caused by overstretching the perineum by the fetal head; however, they are not routinely indicated.  Possible indications for an episiotomy include conditions when the physician anticipates a perineal tear, elderly primigravida, macrosomia, face to pubis delivery, forceps/ventouse delivery, breech delivery, or shoulder dystocia.    

There are two common approaches to an episiotomy; a mediolateral approach and a median approach.  In a mediolateral episiotomy, the incision is made at an angle and proceeds from the vaginal opening diagonally downwards to the left or the right in a straight line that runs an inch away from the anus.  During a mediolateral episiotomy, structures incised include the posterior vaginal wall, superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles, bulbospongiosus, part of the levator ani, subcutaneous tissue, and skin.  

In the median episiotomy, the incision proceeds from the vaginal opening downwards. Median episiotomies bifurcate the perineal body, which supports the female pelvic organs, particularly the posterior vaginal wall. Incision of the perineal body poses a risk of pelvic organ prolapse and urinary incontinence. Midline episiotomies can also extend into the anal sphincter and cause sphincter dysfunction and fecal incontinence.  





Option Analysis

✅ Perineal body :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Anal mucosa:
Incorrect: Fourth-degree perineal tears involve the anal sphincter complex and the anal mucosa. Second-degree perineal tears are limited to the perineal skin and the perineal body.   
❌ Ischiocavernosus muscle :
Incorrect: The ischiocavernosus muscle is a component of the urogenital triangle and the superficial perineal pouch. It arises from the ischial tuberosity and inserts into the crura of the clitoris. It is unlikely to be involved in second-degree perineal tears.   
❌ Internal anal sphincter :
Incorrect: The anal sphincter complex (internal anal sphincter and the external anal sphincter) are damaged in fourth-degree perineal lacerations.   
❌ External anal sphincter :
Incorrect: Severe perineal lacerations of the third and fourth degrees tend to involve the external anal sphincter and result in fecal incontinence.
